statement: Understanding Recurrent Ascites. discomfort, and shortness of breath. 1,2
What Are Your Treatment Options?. Compare your options for managing recurrent ascites.³
Large Volume Paracentesis. drain excess fluid and provide temporary relief from recurrent ascites.3,4

Large Volume Paracentesis. Outpatient procedure
performed in a hospitals

Large Volume Paracentesis. Repetitive procedure
required whenever fluid
builds up impairing QoL6

Large Volume Paracentesis. Up to 97 mins
required per drainage7

Diuretics. Diuretics are medications that increase excretion of sodium and water, aiming to achieve
a negative sodium balance and reduce fluid accumulation in the abdominal cavity.8

Diuretics. Oral administration, especially for
ascites from liver cirrhosis
(requires careful assessment of kidney function,
risk of hypovolemia, and ototoxicity)9

Diuretics. Administered once or
twice daily 10,11

Diuretics. Regular monitoring
required for electrolyte
imbalance or
kidney damage 12,13

allowing patients to drain excess fluid at home. This supports greater independence and
improved quality of life. 14

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. One-time outpatient
procedure to place catheter 15

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Fewer hospitalization
days improving QoL14

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Drainage performed
at home14

hospital-based procedures

Frequency of Use. Diuretics. Daily, long-term therapy¹¹

Category. Row: Frequency of Use | Column: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter | Content: Repeated drainage at home
as needed 14

each time fluid builds up6

Category. Row: Hospital Visits | Column: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter | Content: Hospital visits not required

- Cost of multiple hospital
admissions6

Medical supervision cost12

Drainage bottle cost15

Invasiveness. Diuretics. Non-invasive (oral medication)
Invasiveness. Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Minimally invasive insertion 16

Category. Row: Pain or Side Effects | Column: Large Volume Paracentesis | Content: Hypotension, wound infection,
leakage of fluid at the needle
insertion site

Category. Row: Pain or Side Effects | Column: Diuretics | Content: Electrolyte imbalances,
dehydration, hypotension,
ototoxicity, renal dysfunction13

Category. Row: Pain or Side Effects | Column: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter | Content: Infection and
catheter blockage 16

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Minimally invasive placement: A small tube is inserted through a
tiny abdomen incision during a simple outpatient procedure. 16,17

Simple home drainage: When fluid builds up, connect the tube to a
vacuum bottle. Each session takes 5-15 minutes. 17

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Continuous symptom control: Drain fluid at home, reducing
hospital visits and improving comfort.14

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 100% catheter
placement success. 18

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 76% had no
hospital visits due to
catheter-related
complications.14

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 83% to 100%
of patients enjoyed
relief from
ascites symptoms.19

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Infection rate
as low as
6%.14

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. The catheter is inserted in the abdomen
for draining ascites.20

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. The protective dressing is virtually
undetectable under clothing. 20
